definition:
Fredholm modules represent abstract elliptic pseudo-differential
operators.

An [**odd Fredholm module**]{} $({\mathord{\mathcal{H}}},F)$ over a
$C^*$-algebra $A$ is given by an involutive representation $\pi$ of $A$
on a Hilbert space ${\mathord{\mathcal{H}}}$, together with an operator
$F$ on ${\mathord{\mathcal{H}}}$ such that $F = F^*$,
$F^2 = {\mathord{\mathrm{1\!\!\!\:I}}}$ and
$[F,\pi(a)] \in {\mathbb{K}}({\mathord{\mathcal{H}}})$ for all
$a \in A$.

An [**even Fredholm module**]{} $({\mathord{\mathcal{H}}},F,\Gamma)$ is
given by an odd Fredholm module $({\mathord{\mathcal{H}}},F)$ together
with a ${\mathbb{Z}}_2$-grading $\Gamma$ on ${\mathord{\mathcal{H}}}$,
$\Gamma = \Gamma^*$, $\Gamma^2 = {\mathord{\mathrm{1\!\!\!\:I}}}$, such
that $\Gamma\pi(a) = \pi(a)\Gamma$ and $\Gamma F = -F\Gamma$.

A Fredholm module is called [**degenerate**]{} if $[F,\pi(a)] = 0$ for
all $a \in A$. Degenerate Fredholm modules are homotopic to the
0-module.

An even Fredholm module $({\mathord{\mathcal{H}}},F,\Gamma)$ over
${\mathbb{C}}$ is given by $$\begin{aligned}
{\mathord{\mathcal{H}}}& = & {\mathbb{C}}^k\oplus{\mathbb{C}}^k
\quad\mbox{with\ }
\pi(a) = \left(\begin{array}{cc}
a{\mathord{\mathrm{1\!\!\!\:I}}}_k & 0 \\
0 & 0 \end{array}\right), \\
F & = & \left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & {\mathord{\mathrm{1\!\!\!\:I}}}_k \\
{\mathord{\mathrm{1\!\!\!\:I}}}_k & 0 \end{array}\right), \\
\Gamma & = & \left(\begin{array}{cc}
{\mathord{\mathrm{1\!\!\!\:I}}}_k & 0 \\
0 & -{\mathord{\mathrm{1\!\!\!\:I}}}_k \end{array}\right).\end{aligned}$$
